description: 1675–85; of uncertain origin, possibly from cham, shortening of chambermate, or from comrade. Less likely from Welsh cymrawd (“fellow”), compare brawd (“brother”).

entries.meaning: (dated) A roommate, especially in a college or university.

verbs.description: chum (third-person singular simple present chums, present participle chumming, simple past and past participle chummed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To share rooms with someone; to live together.
examples: Henry Wotton and John Donne began to be friends when, as boys, they chummed together at Oxford, where Donne had gone at the age of twelve years.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lodge (somebody) with another person or people.

examples: "But is that wise when he's the man we've got to diddle?"
"The wisest thing I ever did. To have chummed up with him would have been fatal -- the common dodge."
I'll chum you down to the shops.

description: Originally American English, from the 1850s. Perhaps from Powhatan.

entries.meaning: (fishing, chiefly Canada, US) A mixture of (frequently rancid) fish parts and blood,  dumped into the water as groundbait to attract predator fish, such as sharks

verbs.description: chum (third-person singular simple present chums, present participle chumming, simple past and past participle chummed)

entries.meaning: (fishing, transitive, intransitive) To cast chum into the water to attract fish.
examples: Small live baitfish are effective, and they will take bits of fresh cut fish when chummed strongly.

entries.meaning: (pottery) A coarse mould for holding the clay while being worked on a whirler, lathe or manually.
examples: ...self-supporting chum within the mould normally of corresponding and almost the same but lesser contour, whereby a space is provided between the chum and mould for the introduction of the powdered material and means for expanding the chum'.
